text: (introspective orchestra music)

Hello, I'm Odin,

and today I'm gonna make
another requested prop.

It's Tony Stark's Nano Gauntlet
from "Avengers: Endgame".
(methodical electronic music)

I start with a printout
of the Hot Toys Gauntlet.

Now this is the clearest
picture that I can find.

I scale the gauntlet so
it should fit my hand.
Now, I have concern about how well
Tony's gauntlet actually fits.
You see, Thanos's has more room,
this one is supposed to be a snug fit,
especially around the wrist.
I now try a couple of gloves for the base.

It should be easier than
making fingers from scratch.

Now some of these have
a really good texture,

and a leather glove
would glue really easily,
but it still fits a little too loose.

These knitted jersey
gloves fit really well,
and I think I know how I can get around
the cuff being so snug.
For the rest, I wanted to make a pattern,

like I always do, but trying
to make a pattern on myself

when I'm right-handed,
this was doomed to fail.
(Odin chuckling)
Instead, I measured my arm and wrist,
and measured the thickest part of my hand,

'cause in order for it
to fit into the gauntlet,
my hand must fit through the wrist.
I make a simple start of the cuff

gluing two rings together
with some panels,
which seemed to work.

I want the glove to look like
it's more than just knit,

so I put one on, and slip a
rubber blue glove over it,

and then I put on the knit
glove I actually want to use.

I scrunch over the glove
with a paper drink cup,

so when I coat the knit with
some liquid latex rubber,
I got this jar from a craft store,

the cuff will dry wide open
and be easy to pull on.
You can buy rubberized work gloves,
but they're vulcanized rubber,
which makes them even harder to glue to.

Just some dry liquid
latex takes glue easier
and paints easier, and I put on two gloves
to make sure that my hand

can still easily slip
inside the rubber one
once I have all the foam, and the glue,
and the paint attached to it.
But before I can take it off,
I have to wait for it to dry,
so now I can tell you about my sponsor,
"RAID: Shadow Legends."

This is one of the most
ambitious RPG projects of 2019,
and it can only be compared
with the biggest PC and console titles,
only this one is free.

You can see why there's 10
million players worldwide
in just three months.
I mean, look at these Champions,

and you can play with any
of these in PvP battles,

and I was asked to pick
out my favorite Champion,
but how can I?
Just look at all these guys.

I'm still not even done
play-testing them all,

and I think the game looks
amazing, and I'm not alone.
With over 200,000 reviews,

"RAID" has an almost-perfect
score in the Play Store.
The game always has something new to do,

so you can play for five
minutes or five hours
whenever and wherever.

And, there's now an awesome

Get a new Daily Login Reward

So, what are you waiting for?

as part of the New Player
Program to start your journey.
Now that the glove is dry,
I can use a rod to help remove it.

With contact cement, I can
attach it to the wrist,
and I have a base to start working with.
The back of the hand is basically square

with some knuckle details,
so I make a couple of layers
with some five-millimeter foam,

and the upper layer has a lot
more shape and detail to it.

I build up where the
Mind Stone's gonna go,

which is in the center,
and I use my Dremel

to shape and carve this
piece just a little bit.

It is easier to do this
now before it's glued down.

I want to keep the gauntlet
from getting too bulky,
so most of the panels on the sides

are all gonna be
two-millimeter craft foam.
I wrap the sides of the hand,
but before I can do the cuff,
I need to add some more five-millimeter
for the back of the arm.
I cut out two layers,
but this time I'm gonna Dremel the sides
so they look rounded,
and I glue them down with contact cement.

Now I have an edge for the
side panels on the arm,
and I'm gluing these on as one large piece
because I plan to use my woodburner

to make all the final
detail lines in it later.

I clean up a seam on the
underside, and add a small square.
Like the Infinity Gauntlet,

there is a raised part
on the base of the thumb
where the Time Stone goes.

I cut out a base for
each of the other stones

and glue them over the knuckles
on the back of the gauntlet.

Then I start cutting out all
the pieces for the fingers,
and I crease each one on both sides,

and with three sections on
the back of each finger,

and two on the thumb, this
actually takes a little while.

Then I go ahead and add a strip
to the back of each finger
because, more panel lines.

I heat form the fingertips
over the padded work glove
so it'll actually be rounded and fit.
I'll cut off the excess,
and just glue on the parts that look good.
Then I realized, I need a set
for the pad of each finger as well,

so I get to make five
more and glue them on.

Next, I'll start cutting in the
panel lines for more detail.
Starting with the fingers,
I use a fine point on my woodburning tool

to make wider lines than I
could get with a razor knife.

I take my time, and slowly add
lines to the whole gauntlet.
I use a metal ruler whenever I can
to keep my lines straight,

and I'll add in as many
little details as I can find

by comparing my gauntlet
to the reference photos.

Keep in mind that burning
EVA foam with a woodburner

makes a toxic smoke, so
please, if you do this,
wear a vapor mask, even if you go outside.
With all the lines made,

I spray the whole gauntlet
black with Plasti-Dip,
even the latex palm, which I'm glad to see

the Plast-Dip seems to
stick really well to latex,

so it's actually the
first time I've done it,

but I don't wanna just
spray-paint the palm,
because there's too much movement
when you close your hand and make a fist.
It's gonna crack and peel.

What I want to use
instead is acrylic paints,

so I'll cover this with
tape to keep it safe.
I spray the whole gauntlet

with a nice, shiny silver
paint that I found,
and I end up regretting using this paint,
because it's so slick, and it's so thick

that it cracks and has problems
with the next layer of red
that's gonna go on top of it,
and after adding blue tape
to protect the silver from the red coat,
when I peeled the tape off,
the silver coat needed repainting anyway.

The finish was ruined,
so I should've just used
a bright, aluminum color spray.
I let the gauntlet set overnight
so the paint can fully cure.
After I repaint all the silver,
that super shiny stuff was such a waste,

I paint the palm with a
metallic red acrylic paint.
Acrylics are more flexible than sprays,

and should be able to handle
being closed into a fist.
I add gold paint in between
each raised panel on the fingers,

and paint it around the
inside of each finger as well.

The bottom knuckle layer is
gold, and it takes two coats
to cover over the red metallic car paint.
The palm has more silver panel lines.

I decide to trace the
silver and gold lines
in the palm with a Sharpie.
Now, I know that the Sharpie will run
if I try to apply clear coat to it,

but the metallic spray
paints won't look as good
once they're clear-coated, anyway,
and the result is much nicer
than if I just had the painted colors.
I water down some black paint,

and use a tiny brush to add
it into all the panel lines
that I had cut in.

I go through and carefully
trace out all the lines
on the back of the gloves, on the fingers,
and on the back of the hands,

and because I'm putting
acrylic on top of spray paint,

if I make a mistake, I
can wipe it off easily.
In order to add the Infinity Stones,
I cut into the foam, so when I use epoxy,
it won't just try to stick to the paint.
It'll actually get into all these cracks

and get a really good hold,
and the stones won't fall off.

I'm actually really happy

I think it looks really good,

but I've only really got one complaint.
I don't have any wrist movement.

That's mostly because of
the way I glued it together,
I mean, if I had done it more
like I did Hellboy's Right Hand of Doom,

where the hand was actually
separate from this cuff piece,
or at least I had glued it further up
and allowed it to move around,

that probably would have
been a big improvement.

Instead, my mistake was gluing
it right up to the edge,
so it's got nowhere to go,
but, as it is, I'm pretty happy with it,
and I can almost snap my fingers,
not quite because it's a thick glove.

Honestly, have you ever
